moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bc4 Nf6 4. Ng5: This begins what is called the "fried liver attack!" defendable, if you know how, but oh so tactical!!!
moves.4... d5 5. exd5 Nxd5 6. Nxf7: this is the key to the fried liver, white thinks he is gaining a piece, but it is difficult to keep!
moves.9... c6: this looks nice for white, blacks king is way into the center and black is already getting tied up!
moves.10... Na6 11. d4 Nac7: over protects the knight, but the pawn is hanging...
moves.12. Qxe5+ Kf7 13. Ne4 Qe7 14. O-O Qxe5 1: perhaps this is the losing move. a point is a point, but the king is still exposed, and there is still that passed pawn to deal with.
moves.22... Rxd6 23. f5 Ng5 24. fxg6+ Kxg6: two bishops on an open board!! now how to capitalize on this!!!
which to take with? I like the discovered checks after the rook capture!

opening: two knights defence (C57), Fegatello attack, Leonhardt variation
